item.title: Financial Fine Print and Earnings Restatements
item.description: I examine whether changes in footnotes to financial statements may be used to detect firms that later restate their earnings. I find that when footnotes become longer or more complex, firms are more likely to restate their earnings. I also report that longer and more complex footnotes are associated with a more negative stock market reaction when 10-Ks are filed and greater use of discretionary accruals. CEOs exercise fewer options and analysts are more likely to stop covering firms when footnotes get longer and more complex. My results point to importance of paying attention to changes in footnotes and how footnotes could be used to detect changes in corporate behaviour.
